description: Descriptions and diagnostic criteria for ICD-11 mental, behavioral, and neurodevelopmental disorders
Descriptions and diagnostic criteria for ICD-11 mental, behavioral, and neurodevelopmental disorders

related_diagnoses.disorders due to addictive behaviors: similar to those caused by substance use
related_diagnoses.impulse control disorders: includes several specific conditions like pyromania and kleptomania

description: A group of conditions characterized by cognitive decline.
Includes delirium, mild neurocognitive disorder, amnestic disorder, various forms of dementia.
Relationship distress
Maltreatment by spouse or partner
Problems in relationship between child and caregiver
Child maltreatment
History of spouse or partner violence (physical, sexual, psychological, neglect)

related_diagnoses.Childhood Trauma: Shares Symptoms; Related to Problems Associated with Upbringing and Harmful Events

description: Clinical Descriptions and Diagnostic Requirements

related_diagnoses.alcohol and cannabis use disorders: high concordance among ICD-11, ICD-10, and DSM-IV; substantial difference with DSM-5 regarding mild disorders

description: Syndromes characterized by clinically significant disturbance in an individual's cognition, emotional regulation or behaviour reflecting a dysfunction in the psychological, biological or developmental processes.
These disturbances are usually associated with distress or impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational or other important areas of functioning.
Disturbances usually associated with distress or impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational or other important areas of functioning

The text discusses various articles and research papers regarding the alignment of the ICD-11 classification of disorders due to substance use with global service needs, proposals for paraphilic disorders in ICD-11, public stakeholder comments on ICD-11 chapters related to mental and sexual health, etc.
Definition and diagnostic requirements for ICD-11 mental disorders
Guidance on essential features needed for confident diagnosis.
Flexibility allowed for professional judgment based on patient characteristics and culture.

related_diagnoses.agoraphobia: may involve social anxiety but focuses on fears of being in places or situations where escape might be difficult
related_diagnoses.body dysmorphic disorder: anxiety involving excessive self-consciousness about perceived defects in appearance
related_diagnoses.olfactory reference disorder: anxiety involving excessive self-consciousness about emitting an offensive body odour
related_diagnoses.substance-induced mental disorders: due to the effects of a substance or medication on the CNS
related_diagnoses.secondary mood syndrome: depressive symptoms due to a medical condition classified elsewhere
related_diagnoses.other mental disorders: disorders sharing features with the disorder under consideration

symptoms: fear of specific negative outcomes in social situations

related_diagnoses.anorexia nervosa: symptom overlap can lead to recommending only a single diagnosis
related_diagnoses.bulimia nervosa: symptoms do not meet diagnostic requirements when present alongside another disorder

description: Describes cases where symptoms cannot be attributed solely to another disorder.
Prevents diagnosing a disorder if its symptoms only appear during another disorder.

related_diagnoses.schizotypal disorder: prevents diagnosis if individual had schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder or delusional disorder
related_diagnoses.separation anxiety disorder: may be assigned alongside social anxiety disorder if both criteria are met but different fears trigger the anxiety
related_diagnoses.stereotyped movement disorder: co-occurring diagnosis may be warranted if severity requires additional clinical attention within context of autism spectrum disorder
related_diagnoses.depressive disorders: generalized anxiety disorder should be diagnosed before or after depressive episode according to CDDR for generalized anxiety disorder

description: other specified diagnoses refer to disorders sharing primary clinical features with existing categories
unspecified diagnoses are used when insufficient information is available for a more specific diagnosis

related_diagnoses.schizophrenia: example of a disorder fitting under 'other specified primary psychotic disorder'
related_diagnoses.feeding and eating disorders: example of a group where 'other specified feeding and eating disorder' applies
related_diagnoses.dissociative disorders: example including 'Ganser syndrome' under 'other specified dissociative disorder'

description: Sleep-wake disorders including nightmare disorder, sleepwalking disorder, sleep terrors, and various insomnia, hypersomnia, and circadian rhythm disorders.
Mental, behavioural and neurodevelopmental disorders share relationships with diseases of the nervous system affecting cognition, emotional regulation or behaviour.

related_diagnoses.secondary mental or behavioural syndrome: may be assigned when mental, behavioural or neurodevelopmental syndromes are a direct pathological consequence of a disease of the nervous system

related_diagnoses.premenstrual dysphoric disorder: secondary-parented in the mood disorders grouping
related_diagnoses.gender incongruence: reformulation and renaming of ICD-10 gender identity disorders

related_diagnoses.acute and transient psychotic disorder: includes recoding conventions for episode status and remission
related_diagnoses.mood disorders: examples of postcoordinated symptomatic manifestations provided

description: Recurrent depressive disorder, characterized by recurring episodes of depression.

related_diagnoses.dementia due to Alzheimer disease: severity can be coded using extension codes

description: Classification of mental, behavioral and neurodevelopmental disorders
Double coding convention for secondary mental or behavioral syndromes
Structure of ICD-11 chapters including primary and secondary parents

related_diagnoses.frontotemporal dementia: Neurocognitive disorder due to underlying disease
related_diagnoses.Tourette syndrome: Primary parented in diseases of the nervous system, secondary parented in mental, behavioural and neurodevelopmental disorders

diagnosis: Not applicable (Based on provided text description - it appears to be a general heading about diagnostic requirements)

diagnosis: schizophrenia and other primary psychotic disorders

description: characterized by recurring episodes of depression

diagnosis: Inhalant-, MDMA-, dissociative drug-, other specified psychoactive substance-, multiple specified psychoactive substances-, or unknown/unspecified psychoactive substance-induced mood disorder
description: A group of disorders characterized by mood disturbances resulting from exposure to various psychoactive substances.

related_diagnoses.Manic Episode: Shares symptoms when presenting with manic features.
related_diagnoses.Mixed Episode: Shares symptoms when presenting with both depressive and manic features.

description: Other specified anxiety or fear-related disorder

related_diagnoses.Secondary anxiety syndrome: secondary to disorders and diseases classified elsewhere

description: Characterized by recurrent obsessions and compulsions.

description: Avoidant-restrictive food intake disorder
Pica

description: pattern of substance use or remission

description: A group of conditions caused by using one or more unidentified or specific psychoactive substances.

diagnosis: Unknown or unspecified psychoactive substance dependence

description: A gaming disorder characterized by impaired control over gaming, increasing precedence given to gaming over other interests and daily activities, and continuation or escalation of gaming despite negative consequences.

May include chronic irritability-anger and limitations in prosocial emotions.

description: Prominent personality traits or patterns
A state of temporary but acute mental confusion
Memory loss caused by specific psychoactive substances or medications
A general term for a group of brain disorders that affect memory, thinking, language, judgment, and behavior

description: A group of mental and behavioral disorders arising during or after pregnancy.

description: The presence of significant limitations in intellectual functioning.

Master basic self-care, domestic and practical activities.

symptoms: difficulty coping with significant life changes and traumatic experiences
description: Evidence of a disorder of intellectual development
Markedly reduced cognitive ability and adaptive functioning.

description: Characterized by significant and persistent limitations in intellectual functioning

symptoms: Delays in the acquisition of language skills

Difficulties attending to and following multi-step instructions
Limited ability to anticipate full consequences of actions
description: Disorders affecting intellectual development

Limited vocabulary compared to typically developing peers
Challenges in initiating and participating in activities
Difficulties in matching or organizing items by attributes
Difficulties expressing likes and dislikes in relationships, activities, etc.
Difficulties with literacy and numeracy at varying levels depending on severity
Naivete regarding full consequences of actions or exploitation
Use of simple nonverbal strategies to communicate basic needs
Inability to achieve reading and writing level expected after 4-5 years of schooling (severe)
description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by limitations in intellectual functioning and adaptive behaviors

symptoms: Difficulty expressing likes and dislikes without concrete choices

Struggles differentiating locations and associating meanings
May require support to apply existing abilities for future employment

Development of nonverbal strategies to communicate basic needs
Difficulty recognizing letters from an alphabet
Inability to perform complex tasks even with prompts and aids
Communication challenges regarding future goals, healthcare, and relationships unless provided with concrete choices

description: A group of conditions characterized by limitations in intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior

symptoms: Inability to write more than 20 words from memory
Need for support in behaving appropriately socially
Difficulty sharing information about daily events
Challenges managing conflicts and challenging social interactions

Learning basic work skills later than same-age peers
Use of first names of familiar individuals
Unable to use pronouns, possessives, or regular past tenses
Asking "wh" questions (e.g., when, why, what, where)
Using negatives and relating experiences in simple sentences
Identifying some letters of the alphabet ability
Engaging in reciprocal social interactions support need
Expressing emotions or showing empathy support need
Offering help to others without cues or prompting inability
Showing appropriate emotions in social situations inability
Engaging in conversations or asking others about their interests inability
Transition support need - changing activities or unexpected routines
Starting/ending conversations appropriately with considerable help ability
Saying "please" and "thank you" when appropriate with considerable help ability
Following social rules difficulty including game rules like turn-taking or sharing toys
Participating in social or other games with complex rules inability
Independently putting on and taking off clothing ability
Feeding oneself with hands or spoons ability
Using toilets ability but continuing to need support for tasks like shoe wearing, buttoning clothes, bathing, showering etc.
Learning home and community safety rules and doing household chores inability requiring continued support.
description: A group of conditions characterized by significant limitations both in intellectual functioning and in adaptive behavior

description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by significantly below average intellectual functioning and difficulties with daily living skills

description: Persistent problems causing significant limitations in communication due to reduced intelligibility

related_diagnoses.Anxiety and fear-related disorders: More likely to develop comorbidly with developmental language disorder

symptoms: Errors of pronunciation beyond normal variation for age

description: Speech production disorder without significant intellectual impairment

related_diagnoses.Disorders of Intellectual Development: May coexist; if speech production requires separate attention, both diagnoses may apply.
related_diagnoses.Developmental Speech Fluency Disorder: Can overlap due to disrupted speech flow.

symptoms: Adequate speech production in specific situations but failure to speak in others
Omission or substitution of speech sounds
Distortion of speech sounds due to incorrect tongue placement
Frequent disruptions in the normal rhythmic flow and rate of speech
Repetitions and prolongations in sounds, syllables, words, and phrases
Blocking (silent fixations or inability to initiate sounds)
Markedly reduced speech fluency compared to age expectations
description: Characterized by omission or substitution of speech sounds

related_diagnoses.Selective mutism: May co-occur; shares symptom of inconsistent speaking
related_diagnoses.Dysphonia: Different - characterized by abnormal voice production; no shared symptoms
related_diagnoses.Dysarthria: Motor speech disorder due to neurological issues; distinct from developmental speech sound disorder
related_diagnoses.Secondary speech or language syndrome: Assigned when underlying medical condition causes speech difficulties; excludes developmental speech sound disorder diagnosis in those cases
related_diagnoses.Cerebral palsy, Myasthenia gravis, Senso: Conditions where developmental speech sound disorder diagnosis is excluded; instead, secondary speech or language syndrome is considered if speech sound difficulties are specifically focused upon clinically.

symptoms: Secondary mannerisms like facial grimacing, eye blinking, head movements, and arm/leg movements
Severity varying across situations especially under pressure to communicate
Social anxiety among adolescents and adults exacerbating dysfluency
duration: Relatively brief in many cases; remission possible before puberty.
description: Speech disorder characterized by rapid, irregular speech patterns

symptoms: Disruption of the normal rhythmic flow and rate of speech
Difficulty with speech fluency leading to avoidance or limitation of speaking
Reduced intelligibility affecting communication (in context of differential diagnosis)
duration: Typically persists if not treated effectively, especially in severe cases or late onset.
description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by disruptions in the normal rhythm and flow of speech.
May involve repetitions, prolongations, blocks, interjections, revisions, etc.

impairment of receptive and expressive language
changes in the pattern of language strengths and deficits during development
behavioral, social, adaptive and communication problems persisting into early adulthood

description: characterized by significant deficits in language abilities

symptoms: Delays in language onset or development

related_diagnoses.Disorders of Intellectual Development: May exhibit similar symptoms; both diagnoses may be assigned if criteria are met.

Difficulties with communication and interaction

Lack of social interaction with peers characterized by parallel play or disinterest
Sensory sensitivities to everyday sounds or foods

Marked reactions to even minor change in routines

Reactions to social isolation or the social consequences of inappropriate behavior
description: Early childhood social communication and relationship difficulties

related_diagnoses.Disorders of Intellectual Development: May coexist; ASD diagnosis can still apply if social deficits exceed those expected due to ID.
related_diagnoses.Reactive Aggression/Emotional Changes: Gender-based differential presentations during middle childhood.

description: Persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts.
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: Can co-occur; shares symptoms like impulsivity and hyperactivity but differs in core diagnostic criteria
related_diagnoses.Stereotyped movement disorder: Co-occurrence possible if stereotyped movements cause significant distress or injury
related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: Differentiates based on later onset, absence of restricted, repetitive patterns, and presence of psychotic symptoms
related_diagnoses.Schizotypal disorder: Shares interpersonal difficulties but differs in core diagnostic criteria including restricted, repetitive patterns

description: Characterized by deficits in initiating and sustaining social communication and reciprocal social interactions.
Includes restricted, repetitive and inflexible patterns of behaviour, interests or activities.

related_diagnoses.Selective mutism: Differentiates by presence of deficits in initiating and sustaining social communication and reciprocal social interactions
related_diagnoses.Obsessive-compulsive disorder: Can be distinguished by conscious resistance to impulsive urges to perform compulsive behaviors and absence of deficits in initiating and sustaining social communication and reciprocal social interactions
related_diagnoses.Reactive attachment disorder: Differentiates by lack of significant improvement of autism-like features when moved to a more nurturing environment
related_diagnoses.Disinhibited social engagement disorder: Pattern of indiscriminate social approaches to unfamiliar adults and peers is shared symptom

symptoms: restricted, repetitive and inflexible patterns of behaviour, interests or activities

related_diagnoses.Avoidant-restrictive food intake disorde: may share symptom of restricting food based on sensory characteristics but differs in lack of social communication deficits and restricted, repetitive behaviours.
related_diagnoses.Oppositional defiant disorder: differs in absence of social communication dehaviors and restricted, repetitive behaviors, although demand avoidance can be present.
related_diagnoses.Personality disorder: differs in onset timing and lacks restricted, repetitive behaviors.
related_diagnoses.Primary tics and tic disorders including: differs in nature of movements and presence of premonitory sensory urges.

description: Pervasive developmental disorder marked by difficulties in social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behaviours

Limitations onset typically during early school years.
Learning difficulties manifested in impairments in specific academic skills.

symptoms: Impairments in various underlying psychological processes

Marked difficulties sustaining key academic skills without compensatory strategies, extraordinary effort, or excessive support
Apparent improvement in academic performance under low demand situations but worsening when demands increase
description: A disorder characterized by persistent difficulty in acquiring academic skills despite adequate educational opportunities

duration: Typically persists through adolescence and into adulthood
description: Deficits in reading, mathematics, and written expression
Limitations in acquiring and using academic skills

related_diagnoses.Sensory impairments: Must be differentiated from learning difficulties caused by sensory issues unless appropriate accommodations are made

Affects either gross or fine motor functions or both

related_diagnoses.Developmental Motor Coordination Disorde: Commonly comorbid; clumsiness may overlap but is not diagnostic.
related_diagnoses.Mood Disorders: Can coexist; however, symptoms must predate mood episodes.

related_diagnoses.Intermittent Explosive Disorder: Both involve impulsivity; IED is distinct for its episodic violent outbursts.

symptoms: voluntary, repetitive, stereotyped, apparently purposeless and often rhythmic movements

description: persistent (lasting for several months) voluntary, repetitive, stereotyped movements

symptoms: Stereotyped movements resulting in significant interference with normal daily activities
description: Behaviors like body rocking, head rocking, finger flicking, hand flapping (without self-injury)
Head banging, face slapping, eye poking, biting of hands, lips or other body parts (with self-injury)

symptoms: Self-injury (if movements are a separate focus)

related_diagnoses.Autism spectrum disorder: Differentiated by additional significant limitations in the capacity for reciprocal social interactions and social communication.
related_diagnoses.Obsessive-compulsive disorder: Repetitive behaviours are typically more complex and aimed at neutralizing unwanted intrusive thoughts.
related_diagnoses.Body-focused repetitive behaviour disord: Behaviours directed at the integument (e.g., hair and skin); differs in timing of onset and nature of movements.
related_diagnoses.Tourette syndrome and other tic disorder: Symptoms differ in pattern, predictability, interruption with distraction, age of onset, duration, and absence of premonitory sensory urge.
related_diagnoses.Drug-induced dystonia (tardive dyskinesi: Movement disorder caused by antipsychotic medication; distinct symptom presentation.

description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by repetitive and stereotyped motor movements.
May involve whole-body movements, gait atypicalities, or unusual hand/finger movements.
Presentation characterized by significant difficulties in specific intellectual, motor, language or social functions.
Symptoms don't meet criteria for other neurodevelopmental disorders.

symptoms: Sudden, rapid, non-rhythmic and recurrent movements or vocalizations

Diminution of tics during sleep or focused activities
description: A neurological disorder characterized by multiple motor and phonic tics.

symptoms: Simple motor tics (eye blinking, head jerks)
Complex vocal symptoms including repetition of one's own or others' speech or obscene utterances
Waxing and waning severity of tics
Co-occurrence with other conditions potentially worsening prognosis
duration: Typically diminishes through adolescence; remission possible in early adulthood.
description: A neurological disorder characterized by repetitive, stereotyped movements (tics)
A pattern of co-occurring disorders varies with developmental stage.
Consistent symptoms across cultural groups.

related_diagnoses.autism spectrum disorder: boundary with repetitive and stereotyped motor movements
related_diagnoses.depressive disorder: more likely comorbidity in adolescents and adults
related_diagnoses.substance use disorder: more likely comorbidity in adolescents and adults
related_diagnoses.bipolar disorder: more likely comorbidity in adolescents and adults
related_diagnoses.anxiety and fear-related disorders: women with persistent tic disorders may be more likely to experience
related_diagnoses.depressive disorders: women with persistent tic disorders may be more likely to experience
related_diagnoses.stereotyped movement disorder: boundary with repetitive and stereotyped motor movements

description: Sudden, rapid, non-rhythmic and recurrent movements or vocalizations.
Onset during the developmental period.

related_diagnoses.Self-injurious and self-mutilating behav: Differentiates based on intent behind actions

symptoms: Voluntary suppression of tics for short periods
Diminution of tics during sleep or enjoyable activities
description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent motor and phonic tics.
Tics can be temporarily controlled but tend to recur.

related_diagnoses.Tourette syndrome: May include multiple motor and phonic tics; shares characteristics.

description: Characterized by repetitive, stereotyped motor movements.
May share features with autism spectrum disorder and stereotyped movement disorder.
Can be distinguished from obsessive-compulsive disorder due to their intentional vs unintentional nature.

related_diagnoses.autism spectrum disorder: Shares features like repetitive and stereotyped motor movements
related_diagnoses.stereotyped movement disorder: Shares features like repetitive and stereotyped motor movements
related_diagnoses.obsessive-compulsive disorder: Can coexist; tics differ in being preceded by premonitory sensory urges and not aiming to neutralize obsessions or reduce arousal

description: Definition and diagnostic requirements for ICD-11 mental disorders

diagnosis: Schizophrenia and other primary psychotic disorders
description: grouping of disorders characterized by significant impairments in reality testing

symptoms: cultural expressions of distress misinterpreted as psychotic symptoms
description: Psychotic disorder characterized by at least two of the specified symptoms for a period of 1 month or more

symptoms: experiences of influence, passivity or control
negative symptoms like affective flattening, alogia, avolition, asociality, anhedonia
not caused by substances or medications
description: Primary psychotic disorder characterized by various symptoms

related_diagnoses.schizoaffective disorder: may involve features similar to schizophrenia but with mood disturbance
related_diagnoses.catatonia: can occur as part of schizophrenia (if full syndrome is present)

duration: At least 3 months between episodes; Continuous form has symptoms present for almost all of the course of the disorder.
description: Mental disorder characterized by abnormal social interaction and distorted cognition
Involves delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, and negative symptoms.
Psychosis characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, and negative symptoms.
May involve attenuated psychotic symptoms, anxiety/agitation, varying degrees of depressive symptoms during prodromal or residual phases.

related_diagnoses.Prodromal Phase: Precedes the onset of psychotic symptoms; includes attenuated psychotic symptoms, negative symptoms, anxiety/agitation, or depressive symptoms.
related_diagnoses.Residual Phases: Similar to prodromal phase between acute episodes

symptoms: Negative symptoms persisting and linked to poor prognosis
Cognitive symptoms being persistent and causing functional impairment
Auditory hallucinations as a single voice in children and adolescents
Auditory hallucinations as multiple conversing voices in adults
Delusions and hallucinations difficult to distinguish from normal childhood phenomena
Prominent negative symptoms, hallucinations, and disorganized thinking in children with schizophrenia
description: A mental disorder characterized by multiple persistent symptoms, impairment in cognitive functioning, and other psychosocial problems

related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: May share some symptoms like disorganized thinking and behavior.
related_diagnoses.Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder: May share some symptoms like disorganized thinking and behavior.

duration: persists for at least 1 month in its full, florid form
description: Characterized by persistent hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, experiences of influence, passivity or control, negative symptoms, and disorganized or abnormal psychomotor behavior.

related_diagnoses.Acute and Transient Psychotic Disorder: Symptoms fluctuate rapidly in intensity and type.
related_diagnoses.Delusional Disorder: Persistent delusions without other schizophrenic features.

symptoms: experiences of influence, passivity or control
severe flashbacks involving loss of awareness of present surroundings
intrusive images or memories with hallucinatory quality
description: concurrent presence of schizophrenia and mood disorder symptoms

related_diagnoses.schizophrenia: differentiated based on absence of concurrent mood symptoms meeting criteria for a moderate or severe depressive episode, manic episode, or mixed episode
related_diagnoses.mood disorders: co-occurs with schizophrenia; includes depressive episodes, manic episodes, and mixed episodes
related_diagnoses.post-traumatic stress disorder: may share some symptom overlap but differs in requiring a history of trauma exposure and re-experiencing the traumatic event in the present
related_diagnoses.complex post-traumatic stress disorder: similarly requires a history of trauma exposure and re-experiencing the traumatic event in the present

duration: at least 1 month for both psychotic and mood symptoms
description: Psychotic and mood symptoms occurring simultaneously or within a few days.
Not caused by another medical condition or substances.
Characterized by features of both schizophrenia and mood disorders.
May include periods of remission.
Symptoms fulfilling all diagnostic requirements of schizoaffective disorder have been present for almost all of the course of the disorder during the person’s lifetime since its first onset.
Periods of partial or full remission have been very brief relative to the overall course.

symptoms: loss of interest in work or social activities
neglect of personal appearance or hygiene
description: a mental disorder characterized by a combination of schizophrenia and mood disorder symptoms

related_diagnoses.schizophrenia: similar to but includes mood disorder symptoms

description: A disorder characterized by multiple persistent symptoms, impairment in cognitive functioning and other psychosocial problems.
A mental disorder involving both schizophrenic and mood symptoms.
Psychotic symptoms concurrent with mood symptoms meeting full diagnostic requirements.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: May be distinguished by shorter duration of psychotic symptoms without mood symptoms.
related_diagnoses.Mood episodes with psychotic symptoms: Differs in that psychotic symptoms don't meet schizophrenia criteria.

symptoms: odd, eccentric, unusual or peculiar behaviour or appearance
poor rapport with others and social withdrawal
perceptual distortions like illusions, depersonalization, derealization, or hallucinations
vague, circumstantial, metaphorical, overelaborate or stereotyped thinking
description: An enduring pattern of unusual speech, perceptions, beliefs and behaviours

related_diagnoses.schizophrenia: part of the spectrum of schizophrenia-related psychopathology

symptoms: vague, circumstantial, metaphorical, overelaborate or stereotyped thinking
description: a mental disorder characterized by eccentric thoughts and behaviors that cause significant distress or impairment.
includes symptoms like social anxiety, paranoia, and unusual thought patterns.
Enduring disturbance in the individual’s way of interpreting and experiencing themselves, others and the world

related_diagnoses.schizophrenia: may experience similar symptoms during prodromal and residual phases; differs in severity and duration of psychotic symptoms
related_diagnoses.autism spectrum disorder: interpersonal difficulties may share some features, but no restricted, repetitive and stereotyped patterns of behaviour
related_diagnoses.personality disorder: should not receive additional diagnosis due to disturbances in functioning and interpersonal relations - these are inherent to schizotypal disorder itself

symptoms: experiences of influence, passivity or control
duration: does not exceed 3 months, usually lasting from a few days to 1 month
description: Sudden onset of psychotic symptoms without a prodrome.
Rapidly changing symptoms in nature and intensity.

duration: Typically brief, often resolving within weeks to months.
description: Brief psychotic episode characterized by sudden onset of psychosis without clear cause.

related_diagnoses.Schizophrenia: May share similar symptoms but differs in duration and course.
related_diagnoses.Other Psychotic Disorders: Falls under the broader category of primary psychotic disorders.

fluctuating disturbances of mood and affect
transient states of perplexity or confusion
duration: usually less than 3 months per episode; periods of full remission between episodes lasting at least 3 months
description: sudden onset psychosis that resolves without treatment or with minimal intervention

duration: lasting anywhere from a few days but not exceeding 3 months
description: Isolated unusual subjective experiences...
